problem: Two rational numbers $ rac{m}{n}$ and $ rac{n}{m}$ are written on a blackboard, where $m$ and $n$ are relatively prime positive integers. At any point, Evan may pick two of the numbers $x$ and $y$ written on the board and write either their arithmetic mean $ rac{x+y}{2}$ or their harmonic mean $ rac{2xy}{x+y}$ on the board as well. Find all pairs $(m,n)$ such that Evan can write $1$ on the board in finitely many steps.

solutions.Solution:
We claim that all odd $m, n$ work if $m+n$ is a positive power of 2.
Proof:
We first prove that $m+n=2^k$ works. By weighted averages we have that $\frac{n(\frac{m}{n})+(2^k-n)\frac{n}{m}}{2^k}=\frac{m+n}{2^k}=1$ can be written, so the solution set does indeed work. We will now prove these are the only solutions.
Assume that $m+n\ne 2^k$, so then $m+n\equiv 0\pmod{p}$ for some odd prime $p$. Then $m\equiv -n\pmod{p}$, so $\frac{m}{n}\equiv \frac{n}{m}\equiv -1\pmod{p}$. We see that the arithmetic mean is $\frac{-1+(-1)}{2}\equiv -1\pmod{p}$ and the harmonic mean is $\frac{2(-1)(-1)}{-1+(-1)}\equiv -1\pmod{p}$, so if 1 can be written then $1\equiv -1\pmod{p}$ and $2\equiv 0\pmod{p}$ which is obviously impossible, and we are done.
